text:
Also at 150 Seaport, I had asked the developer, @BostonPlans & @MassDEP to delineate the area(s) of Harborwalk that were going to be public, free of charge, from areas of Harborwalk licensed for restaurant patio use.

No delineation was provided. From experience, it will matter.
text_html: Also at 150 Seaport, I had asked the developer, @BostonPlans & @MassDEP to delineate the area(s) of Harborwalk that were going to be public, free of charge, from areas of Harborwalk licensed for restaurant patio use. No delineation was provided. From experience, it will matter.

text:
As for 150 Seaport, I had asked the developer, @BostonPlans & @MassDEP to consider a 2,500 sf civic or cultural use, carved from a proposed 10,700 sf restaurant, in fulfillment of Chapter 91 obligations. 

As I understand, the project will have a 500 sf "public waiting area."
text_html: As for 150 Seaport, I had asked the developer, @BostonPlans & @MassDEP to consider a 2,500 sf civic or cultural use, carved from a proposed 10,700 sf restaurant, in fulfillment of Chapter 91 obligations. As I understand, the project will have a 500 sf "public waiting area."

text: People are so desparate for affordable housing that we let @BostonPlans deepen the lines of economic segregation. Stirring fears of gentrification distracts people from the fact we still keep the poor out of high opportunity neighborhoods.
text_html: People are so desparate for affordable housing that we let @BostonPlans deepen the lines of economic segregation. Stirring fears of gentrification distracts people from the fact we still keep the poor out of high opportunity neighborhoods.

text: Is it worth noting that while approximately 525,000 square feet of civic and cultural uses vanished since the initial project filing, the total project size increased from 6.5 million square feet (PNF, 2008) to 7.7 million square feet this year (Restated PDA, 2010)?
text_html: Is it worth noting that while approximately 525,000 square feet of civic and cultural uses vanished since the initial project filing, the total project size increased from 6.5 million square feet (PNF, 2008) to 7.7 million square feet this year (Restated PDA, 2010)?

text: @BostonPlans and @BostonBTD are experimenting with prohibiting residents of some new apartment buildings in Boston from obtaining on-street parking permits. Written into the lease -- if you own a vehicle and register it in MA, it has to be stored off-street.

text:
Misleading & false. New bldgs require a stormwater mgmt plan to capture h20 from all impervious 
surfaces and recapture 90% of all rain events back into 
drainage structures which recharge water back into the ground. Pkg lot  simply sheds water offsite and onto streets.
text_html: Misleading & false. New bldgs require a stormwater mgmt plan to capture h20 from all impervious surfaces and recapture 90% of all rain events back into drainage structures which recharge water back into the ground. Pkg lot simply sheds water offsite and onto streets.

text: It's the front yard of condos. In my view, there have been too many moves like this by Fan Pier's master developer that quell public engagement. That includes design of the public spaces, the music piped from rocks, the obsessive signage and the lack of regular event programming.

text: Café in a standalone space between Harborwalk and Harbor, master planned and approved under Chapter 91 by @BostonPlans and @MassDEP, on a waterfront envisioned as a year-round destination, is closed in fall, winter and spring. Who benefits from buttoning up? Condo owners. pic.twitter.com/N2o14xM8Ie

text: BWSC is doing great work but the drainage system doesn’t have capacity for storing anticipated volumes of water. That’s why landowners /developers must be held accountable, not simply pushing stormwater/floodwater away from new project sites.

text: .@BosSkateboarder Not sure if you're still on Twitter, but can you and/or friends confirm if skateboarders are banned from Fan Pier's streets? I'm not talking abt sidewalks or Harborwalk, just streets. Hoping to understand @BostonPlans approvals with respect to public easements.
text_html: .@BosSkateboarder Not sure if you're still on Twitter, but can you and/or friends confirm if skateboarders are banned from Fan Pier's streets? I'm not talking abt sidewalks or Harborwalk, just streets. Hoping to understand @BostonPlans approvals with respect to public easements.

text: Apparently skateboarders are prohibited from riding on any Fan Pier streets. The streets are privately owned with a public easement. We have a long history of BPDA allowing landowners to run roughshod over public access. Will BPDA claim it has no leverage to do better? Nonsense.

text:
Building more housing than in decades is meaningless. I remember the same conversation in prior administration w respect to BRA. We're talking about balanced land use here.

text: A few numbers I just found. From 2014-17, Boston built 6.9M SF of office space (net gain = 3.3M SF). It built 20.9M sf of housing. Same years, @bostonplans approved 9.2M sf of office, 25.1M sf of residential. Is that an imbalance? I'm not sure. (Pg. 15-21) http://www.bostonplans.org/getattachment/4c9b4906-bf32-4933-a20a-b6180a610f10 …

text: Received final e-mail notice from David Carlson of @BostonPlans. While I remain an unrelenting critic of 21st century large architecture, Mr. Carlson served Boston well and was exceptionally fair to citizen-attendees. We must work to make BCDC regulatory, not advisory. TY, DC.

text:
Curious, Jon. Is @BostonPlans buying land from HYM for civic uses (police, fire, community ctr, etc.) to serve a new n'hood at Suffolk Downs?

Because BRA (BPDA) claimed civic uses would be the responsibility of the big 3 Seaport master developers and we know how that worked out.

text: True, and jurisdictions vary. I'm not sure why BPDA was tasked to redesign Congress St and Summer St within Fort Point, but their planners worked with BTD and —aside from a 10-year delay securing funding, it proved to be a remarkably solid effort. Albeit, w/o dedicated bus lanes.
text_html: True, and jurisdictions vary. I'm not sure why BPDA was tasked to redesign Congress St and Summer St within Fort Point, but their planners worked with BTD and —aside from a 10-year delay securing funding, it proved to be a remarkably solid effort. Albeit, w/o dedicated bus lanes.

text: One note... BPDA probably isn't responsible for transit planning here. The BPDA Crossroads Plan now under construction on Summer St in Fort Point (that might also benefit from dedicated bus lanes) exclusively tackled the redesign of the area within the bounds of Fort Point.

text: As for me, I look fwd to the report in May. The proposal for intermediate steps at the Open House focuses on Channel seawall. As you're aware, small property owners have been susceptible to floodwater/stormwater rising from drains, not water arriving over the seawall. Thank you.
text_html: As for me, I look fwd to the report in May. The proposal for intermediate steps at the Open House focuses on Channel seawall. As you're aware, small property owners have been susceptible to floodwater/stormwater rising from drains, not water arriving over the seawall. Thank you.

text: No, but the 2018 PDA amendment that shifts Fan Pier to 71% office space, away from long-stated planning objectives, is the 1st amendment on Fan Pan since BPDA was audited by McKinsey. I was giving this post-audit BPDA a chance to right itself, and am routinely being disappointed.
text_html: No, but the 2018 PDA amendment that shifts Fan Pier to 71% office space, away from long-stated planning objectives, is the 1st amendment on Fan Pan since BPDA was audited by McKinsey. I was giving this post-audit BPDA a chance to right itself, and am routinely being disappointed.

text: Step #1 @BostonPlans: Making new large projects (over 100k sf) resilient against sea level rise must be mandatory, not voluntary. Our existing buildings shouldn't be facing floodwaters flowing from ridiculous amounts of new BPDA-approved privately developed hardscape surfaces.

text: As a #ClimateReadyBoston leader, I agree. We are here to support the city. @BostonPlans, @GreenovateBos: How we can help you? Let's send out alerts before storms to move cars from streets KNOWN to flood, put up temporary protective walls, document reach, and expedite mitigation.
text_html: As a #ClimateReadyBoston leader, I agree. We are here to support the city. @BostonPlans, @GreenovateBos: How we can help you? Let's send out alerts before storms to move cars from streets KNOWN to flood, put up temporary protective walls, document reach, and expedite mitigation.

text:
From my experience, residents with cars are going to be protective of on-street parking, calling for as many off-street spaces as possible. 

Those who don't own cars will be agnostic.

What's needed on transit is leadership, planning, sound policy and enforcement. Not input.
text_html: From my experience, residents with cars are going to be protective of on-street parking, calling for as many off-street spaces as possible. Those who don't own cars will be agnostic. What's needed on transit is leadership, planning, sound policy and enforcement. Not input.

text: There's no reason the @BostonPlans  needs to accept that parking change, and that's the kind of leadership I'm looking for from the agency. We can also ask them to do a better job in outreach/education.
text_html: There's no reason the @BostonPlans needs to accept that parking change, and that's the kind of leadership I'm looking for from the agency. We can also ask them to do a better job in outreach/education.

text: Point being, if we're reading that "City officials cite signs of rent stabilization, with rental increases of 1.5 percent from 2018 to 2019," I'd like to see hard data and info on how projected demand (e.g. new jobs, etc) is being factored into claims regarding "stabilization."

text: OK. But I've heard (paraphrased) "we're on track" since I moved here in 1990. It's a widespread misconception that Boston is only recently reeling from a crisis. It's been consistent for two decades. 1400sf market rate unit in Fort Point in 1990 was $1400/mo. $2800/mo in 2000.

text: Understood. I was just making the point that COB, BPDA and community lose nearly all leverage upon PDA approval. Additional investments expected by COB, BPDA or community will either require public $$$ or will be breadcrumbs derived from future horsetrading in PDA amendments.
text_html: Understood. I was just making the point that COB, BPDA and community lose nearly all leverage upon PDA approval. Additional investments expected by COB, BPDA or community will either require public $$$ or will be breadcrumbs derived from future horsetrading in PDA amendments.

text: I'll add that IMHO it doesn't matter who owns the land. What matters is that the land benefits from its location in Boston and dependence on public resources. Once the PDA is approved, HYM holds all the cards in terms of who pays for additional investments.
text_html: I'll add that IMHO it doesn't matter who owns the land. What matters is that the land benefits from its location in Boston and dependence on public resources. Once the PDA is approved, HYM holds all the cards in terms of who pays for additional investments.
